title: In New York State Rifle & Pistol Association Inc. v. City of New York, NY (NYC), will the Supreme Court rule that NYC’s previous ban on transporting a licensed, locked, and unloaded handgun to a home or shooting range outside city limits is unconstitutional?
preds: They declared it moot. I got this one totally wrong.

Now that it is Moot [NYC changed the Laws involved] and the Court has better things to worry about this term video Teleconferences  https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-for-first-time-to-hold-arguments-via-teleconference-next-month/2020/04/13/f7e325d0-7d8d-11ea-a3ee-13e1ae0a3571_story.html
After a much-anticipated showdown over gun regulations at the U.S. Supreme Court in early December focused on procedure over substance, advocates on all sides are waiting to see if the court dismisses the case. The court heard arguments on Dec. 2 in New York State Rifle & Pistol Association Inc. v. City of New York, New York. Rather than focus on the Second Amendment, much of the discussion centered on whether the court should even discuss gun issues at all.
Instead, the court focused on whether the repeal of the law at the center of the case made the issue moot. “What you’re asking us to do is to take a case in which the other side has thrown in the towel and completely given you every single thing you demanded,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor told lawyers for the plaintiffs. The New York State Rifle and Pistol Association (NYSRPA) is challenging a New York City law that severely restricted the transport of firearms outside the home. In June, after the Supreme Court agreed to hear NYSRPA’s appeal, the city repealed the law. The justices focused for much of the hearing on whether the case was moot. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg quickly redirected the lawyer for the gun owners, Paul Clement, away from discussing the Second Amendment issues. Instead, Ginsburg went right to the mootness question. https://www.opb.org/news/article/us-supreme-court-gun-regulations-rights-control-cases/ https://nypost.com/2020/04/14/supreme-court-will-hear-cases-via-teleconference-for-first-time/

Miller, S., A. & Keehan, K., A. (2020). NY Firearm Restriction Faces Mootness Challenge in Supreme Court. Law Com. The Legal Intelligencer March 04, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.law.com/thelegalintelligencer/2020/03/04/ny-firearm-restriction-faces-mootness-challenge-in-supreme-court/ The Constitution permits judges to adjudicate only actual, ongoing cases or controversies. A case can become “moot,” even on appeal, when the issues litigated are no longer in dispute—for example, when a challenged law is repealed. However, there are exceptions to the mootness doctrine. For example, a government entity’s voluntary cessation of challenged activity will only result in a dismissal for mootness if there is no reasonable expectation that the challenged violation will resume. That is the issue in New York State Rifle and Pistol Association v. City of New York, a case currently before the U.S. Supreme Court. = Mogilnicki, E., K.  & Schultz, A.  (2020) The Incomplete Record in New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. City of New York, 73 SMU L. REV. F. 1 Retrieved from
https://scholar.smu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1006&context=smulrforum

This comes down to guessing whether they're going to decide it or declare it moot and decide the next one.  My inclination is to go with the latter.  (Full disclosure:  Nobody on the Court confides in me, nor should they.)
Given composition of the Court yes.
Low risk. Don't want to unnecessarily irk the NRA on this issue.

They will moot this one out, but whoever writes the majority opinion will toss in some obiter dictum to the effect that a similar live law would be closely scrutinized, or some such giveaway phrase.   At least one concurring opinion, probably Kagan's, will take indirect and polite exception to that.

Given the current make up of SCOTUS, it's highly likely that they will make the adoption of such restrictions on gun owners less likely by ruling against laws like NYC's. But there is also a small chance that since NYC decided to rescind the law, SCOTUS will not render a final decision on the validity of the law.
Also, I think many respondents are misreading the question.
The truth of guns in the US--that they are only instruments, utensils and that the user is to blame--is becoming abundantly used and clear. The court will follow.

Ok so the way I read this if you have your firearm in your house according to this law from New York state or city you would not be able to take your firearm on a hunting trip to upstate New York where hunting deer or if you really want to call a Bambi is a yearly event from little boys that are just growing up to shoot their first but two old men that have only a little time left to shoot their last buck.
As a person with cognitive thinking this law just has no logical l merits.

The challengers highlight three elements for the court (2nd amendment, commerce clause, and the right to travel), setting up a potentially wide scope and impact of a ruling.  Based on the NY legal changes and the questions posed by the Justices during arguments, it appears very unlikely the Court will act decisively.  The case will likely be returned as moot.

Previous firearm related decisions have considered the reasonableness of compliance with the law.  In this case, an activity was deemed lawful, but the law was preventing the activity by needlessly complicating that activity.

New York is not natural NRA territory and there is a degree of sensitivity (not enough, to most Europeans) to the latest mass shootings so a lot can happen by July. However, on points of usage: if it is locked, unloaded and licenced, what is the purpose of transporting the weapon? If it is to be used up country or out of state, how can this be distinguished from transporting the weapon for purposes of trade, and what limits are there on the trading of weapons within and outside the city and state boundaries? If it is for trade, what measures are in place for the mandatory 'cooling off' and safety check period on gun sales or does this not apply to private traders? Owning a gun may be protected by the Constitution - although not in all opinions - but trading one is not.
I think the court will determine the question is moot.
The shift of the Supreme Court to the right
I think they'll go 5-4 or maybe 6-3 for moot on this case and wait for one that's more fun for them.

The US is wedded to its right to bear arms constitutional right. This would therefore be a legal precedent  that could be followed elsewhere. I don’t think the Supreme Court will rule in NYCs favour. Although they ought to!

Supreme Court shows little appetite for expanding gun rights in arguments over repealed New York regulation KEY POINTS
•	The Supreme Court seemed unlikely to deliver a major win for gun-rights activists during arguments in the first significant Second Amendment case the justices had heard in nearly a decade.
•	Some of the court’s conservatives, including Justices Neil Gorsuch and Samuel Alito, seemed eager to use the case to address the reach of the Second Amendment.
•	But it appeared likely that Chief Justice John Roberts would side with the court’s liberals to dismiss the matter altogether as moot.
•	Search Engine: The case is
•	 “New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. City of New York, No. 18-280”. Higgins (2019) Dec. 2, stated that: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed unlikely to deliver a major win for gun-rights activists during arguments on Monday in the first significant Second Amendment case the justices have heard in nearly a decade (Para. 1). While court conservatives including Justices Neil Gorsuch and Samuel Alito seemed eager to use the case to address the reach of the Second Amendment, it appeared likely after an hour of arguments that Chief Justice John Roberts would side with the court’s liberals to dismiss the matter altogether as moot in light of the repeal of the regulation (Para. 3). A decision in thew New York case is expected by July, in the midst of the 2020 presidential election. The nation’s gun laws have become one of the key issues in the Democratic race amidst an uptick in mass-shooting deaths and youth-led activism, though substantive new legislation is seen as all-but-impossible for the foreseeable future under divided government (Para. 5). One wrinkle during arguments came from a difference in opinion between Clement and Jeffrey Wall, the Justice Department’s principal deputy solicitor general, who was arguing in favor of the gun owners (Para. 22).
Wall said it was a “close call” and a “hard question” but stopped short of endorsing the argument. Instead, Wall emphasized that the gun owners could still seek monetary damages (Para. 25). All in all, the justices spent just a few minutes probing the key constitutional question that gun-control activists feared would be on the table and that gun-rights groups hoped the court would address. Since the court’s landmark 2008 opinion in D.C. v. Heller, the lower courts have generally weighed the public interest in gun laws as part of their consideration of whether they are legal. Using that methodology, appeals courts have upheld a broad range of gun restrictions, and those laws have remained on the books as the Supreme Court refused to review them (Para. 27). *
References Higgins, T. (2019). Supreme Court shows little appetite for expanding gun rights in arguments over repealed New York regulation. CNBC. Politics. Dec. 2, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/12/02/supreme-court-shows-little-appetite-for-expanding-gun-rights.html Supreme Court Website (2019). New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. City of New York, No. 18-280. Supreme Court. Retrieved from
https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?Search=+No.+18-280&type=Site
I think they'll take a pass on this one and wait for something less moot to come up.

The Court ruling is in the last line of this excerpt from the scotus post the probably going to throw it out because this state repealed the ruling.
This morning the Supreme Court heard oral argument in a challenge to the constitutionality of a New York City rule that barred gun owners from taking their licensed guns outside the city. The gun owners argued that the rule violated their right to “keep and bear arms” under the Constitution’s Second Amendment. But it’s not clear that the justices will reach the merits of the gun owners’ complaint. Instead, it seemed possible (although far from certain) that they could throw out the case because the dispute is now moot – that is, no longer a live controversy – after the city repealed the rule last summer
Assuming it is not declared moot, than yes they will likely rule it unconstitutional.

Oops--had a 5 there, which was a typo.   We were much more careful to avoid errors when I was a lad and we carved our messages on rocks--too difficult to make corrections.  Sadly, many proofreaders were reduced to penury and had to Dumpster-dive for food and clothing.

@Econja2018 raises a point that I had overlooked or forgotten about:  The Court will give it a miss if there is no existing controversy, and this one is certainly easy to declare moot.  Since appellate courts in the US have a general practice of not deciding anything they don't have to, or for other reasons would rather not, I'm coming 'way down on this one; probably will come down some more as life wears on.  Thanks, @Econja2018.

If the court says the case is moot then this question closes as NO. If the court decides it then The conservative court will probably go Yes.  I think the court will say the original controversy is moot.  There are other issues with New York law that need to go back through the lower courts.
